title: Color Mixing Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of color theory and mixing!

questions.question: What color do you get when you mix red and blue paint?
questions.explanation: Mixing red and blue paint creates purple (or violet). These are two of the three primary colors in traditional color theory.

questions.question: What color do you get when you mix red and yellow paint?
questions.explanation: Mixing red and yellow paint creates orange. Orange is one of the three secondary colors in traditional color theory.

questions.question: What are the three primary colors in traditional (subtractive) color mixing?
questions.explanation: In traditional (artistic) color theory, the three primary colors are red, yellow, and blue. These colors cannot be made by mixing other colors together.

questions.question: What color do you get when you mix blue and yellow paint?
questions.explanation: Mixing blue and yellow paint creates green. Green is one of the three secondary colors.

questions.question: What happens when you mix all three primary paint colors (red, yellow, blue) together?
questions.explanation: Mixing all three primary paint colors together typically produces a muddy brown or dark gray. This is because paint mixing is subtractive â€” each color absorbs more light.

questions.question: In light mixing (additive color), what color do you get when you combine red and green light?
questions.explanation: In additive color mixing (light), combining red and green light creates yellow. This is different from paint mixing and is used in TV and computer screens.

questions.question: What is the complementary color of red on a standard color wheel?
questions.explanation: Green is the complementary color of red. Complementary colors are directly opposite each other on the color wheel and create high contrast when placed together.

questions.question: What color do you get when you mix red and white paint?
questions.explanation: Mixing red and white paint creates pink. Adding white to any color creates a 'tint' of that color, making it lighter and less saturated.

questions.question: What is the term for adding black to a color to make it darker?
questions.explanation: Adding black to a color creates a 'shade.' Adding white creates a 'tint,' and adding gray creates a 'tone.'

questions.question: In printing (CMYK), what are the primary colors?
questions.explanation: In CMYK printing, the primary colors are Cyan, Magenta, and Yellow (with K for Key/Black). These are the subtractive primaries used in modern printing.

questions.question: What color results from mixing orange and blue paint in equal amounts?
questions.explanation: Mixing orange and blue (complementary colors) in equal amounts produces brown. Mixing complementary colors together always tends to neutralize them toward brown or gray.

questions.question: In additive color mixing (light), what do you get when you combine all three primary colors (red, green, blue) at full intensity?
questions.explanation: Combining red, green, and blue light at full intensity creates white light. This is the basis of RGB color used in screens and displays.

questions.question: What is a 'triadic' color scheme?
options: Three shades of the same color
Three colors equally spaced on the color wheel
questions.explanation: A triadic color scheme uses three colors that are equally spaced around the color wheel (120 degrees apart), such as red, yellow, and blue.

questions.question: What are 'warm' colors typically associated with?
questions.explanation: Warm colors include red, orange, and yellow. They are associated with energy, warmth, and vibrancy, and tend to advance visually in a composition.

questions.question: What is 'color value' in art and design?
options: The lightness or darkness of a color
questions.explanation: Color value refers to the lightness or darkness of a color. It is one of the three properties of color, along with hue (the color itself) and saturation (intensity).
